content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been having a rough time sleeping lately. I’m dealing with a lot of stress at work, and it’s keeping me up at night. My mind starts racing with the “what ifs,” especially about losing my job and not being able to support my family. My partner suggested I try therapy, so here I am, but honestly, I’m not sure how this will help.

It sounds like you're under a lot of pressure right now, and the sleepless nights combined with worries about work and your family seem overwhelming. It’s understandable that you might feel unsure about how therapy could help. What are your thoughts about what you would like to get out of this conversation today?

I guess I’m just looking for anything that might help me stop overthinking at night and actually get some sleep. If I could get that sorted, maybe I’d have more energy to deal with everything going on at work. I really don’t know how to fix any of it, though.

It sounds like sleep is a big priority for you right now, and you’re hoping that better rest would help you face work challenges with more energy. Feeling stuck and not knowing where to start can be really tough. What steps have you tried so far, if any, to manage your overthinking or improve your sleep?

Honestly, I haven’t done much. I’ve tried things like cutting back on caffeine or laying in bed earlier, but once my head hits the pillow, everything just spirals. I end up staring at the ceiling or scrolling on my phone until it’s really late. It’s frustrating because I feel like I can’t turn my brain off.

That sounds really frustrating—you're putting in effort to make changes, but your mind is still racing when you want it to calm down. It’s clear that you're trying, even though it’s been challenging. What do you think makes it hardest to stop your thoughts from spiraling at night?

I think it’s the uncertainty about work and these “what if” scenarios that won’t leave my head. Like, I can’t stop thinking about all the ways things could go wrong—getting fired, not being able to pay bills, disappointing my family. It feels like once those thoughts start, there’s no way to shut them down.

It sounds like those worries feel very real and urgent, especially when you're alone with your thoughts at night. The fear of losing control over things like your job and providing for your family seems to be weighing heavily on you. What do those “what if” thoughts mean to you in terms of how you view yourself or your current situation?

I guess they make me feel like I’m failing, or that no matter how hard I try, it might not be enough. I want to be a good provider, a good partner, and a good parent, but it feels like everything might slip through my fingers, and I wouldn’t know how to fix it.

You care deeply about being there for your family and doing your best, which says a lot about your values and the kind of person you strive to be. Right now, it seems like the weight of those expectations and fears of losing control are making it hard for you to feel secure or confident in your efforts. What would it mean for you if you could find a way to feel more in control or at peace in these moments?

It would mean everything, honestly. Just feeling like I had a handle on things or that I wasn’t constantly on the verge of losing it all would make such a difference. I just don’t know how to get to that point when everything feels so uncertain right now.

Having a sense of control and peace sounds deeply important to you, especially with all the uncertainty you're facing. It’s clear that you’re looking for ways to feel more grounded and steady, even when things are unpredictable. What do you think is one small step—or even a change in focus—that might help you move toward that sense of calm or control?
Sorry, I can’t think of anything right now. That’s kind of why I’m here—I just feel stuck. I don’t know what would work or what would make any of this easier.

It's okay to feel stuck right now, and it makes sense that you're looking for some support to figure out what might help. You’ve already shown strength by being open about your struggles and seeking help, and that’s an important step. If you'd like, we could explore more about what makes you feel stuck and brainstorm together when you're ready. Would it also be helpful to review any sleep patterns or other data that might give you more insight into how everything is affecting you lately?

It's okay to feel stuck right now, and it sounds like you're carrying a lot on your shoulders. Even though it feels overwhelming, taking this step of talking about it is really brave. Maybe we can start small—what does winding down at night usually look like for you right now?

Right now, winding down mostly means laying in bed worrying or scrolling on my phone until I feel too tired to stay awake. I guess I don’t really have much of a routine to help me relax because I’m just trying to make it through the night. I can’t even think about patterns or data when I’m feeling this drained.

I usually just lie there thinking about everything, or if it gets too bad, I’ll grab my phone and start scrolling through social media or the news to distract myself. But honestly, that probably just makes things worse because then I’m wide awake. I don’t really have any kind of proper routine for winding down, I just hope that at some point I’ll get tired enough to knock out.

It sounds like nights feel really draining for you, and the scrolling seems like a way to distract yourself from those racing thoughts, even though it might keep you more awake in the end. It’s tough to face those sleepless moments without a routine that helps you feel calm. What do you think might help you feel more prepared to let go of the day’s worries before you head to bed?

It sounds like nights are pretty overwhelming for you, and it’s hard to feel calm when you’re stuck in your thoughts. Coming up with a small, calming routine might give your brain a chance to wind down gradually—something simple like listening to relaxing music, journaling for a few minutes, or even just stepping away from your phone for a bit before bed. Do you think trying one of those might feel manageable?

It could be worth a shot. I’ve never really tried journaling, but maybe writing things down would help me get some of those thoughts out of my head. Stepping away from my phone might be tough, though—it’s kind of my go-to distraction. I guess I could try something small first and see how it goes.
